But wait: the output of Program 1 is a long integer (as a string without commas) and the input to Program 2 is that integer as a string? Then Program 2 would replace commas in that string.

  - Read the input string (as a token, i.e., a word). - Process the string: replace every occurrence of "BC" with "D". We can do this by scanning the string and building a new string. Note: the original replacement is global and non-overlapping. We can do:

  But note: the original Java program uses `replaceAll` which uses regex and replaces all occurrences. We must do the same: non-overlapping and left-to-right. Alternatively, we can do:

        s = trim(input)
        do while (index(s, "BC") > 0)
            pos = index(s, "BC")

            s = s(1:pos-1) // 'D' // s(pos+2:)
        end do But that might be inefficient for long strings. But the problem constraints? We don't know. We can do a one-pass scanning to build the new string. Let me do:

        character(len=200000) :: s, t
        integer :: i, n

        read(*,*) s   ! read the token
        n = len_trim(s)
        t = ''        ! but we need to build t

        i = 1

                t = trim(t) // 'D'

        character(len=200000) :: s, t

        read(*,*) s
        n = len_trim(s)
        t = ''   ! initialize to empty

        i = 1
        j = 0
        do while (i <= n)
            if (i < n .and. s(i:i+1) == "BC") then
                ! We are going to put a 'D'
                j = j + 1
                t(j:j) = 'D'

In Fortran, we can use integer(kind=8) if necessary? The Java program uses `long cnt`. So we should use a 64-bit integer. So:

        integer(kind=8) :: tmp, cnt

  However, the input string length? The problem doesn't specify. But the counting might be large? So we use integer(kind=8) for tmp and cnt. Steps:

  1. Read the input string (we assume maximum length 200000? but the problem doesn't specify. We can use a large enough length). 2. Build the new string t by replacing every "BC" with "D".

children.text:
4. Write the integer cnt without any formatting (using I0 format) to avoid extra spaces. But note: the input string might be long. We have to set the character variable length to a maximum. The problem doesn't specify, but we can set it to 200000. Let me write the code accordingly. Important: We must not do any I/O in the middle. So the entire Fortran program:

```fortran
program main
    implicit none
    character(len=200000) :: s, t
    integer :: i, j, n
    integer(kind=8) :: tmp, cnt  ! to match Java's long

    ! Read the input string (as a single token, which is the entire word)
    read(*,*) s
    n = len_trim(s)

    ! Build the new string t by replacing "BC" with "D"
    t = ''  ! Initialize to blanks? Actually, we are going to assign by index, so we can set to blanks and then assign. j = 0 i = 1
    do while (i <= n) if (i < n) then
            if (s(i:i+1) == "BC") then
                j = j + 1
                t(j:j) = 'D'
                i = i + 2
                cycle
            end if
        end if
        ! If we are here, we take one character
        j = j + 1
        t(j:j) = s(i:i) i = i + 1
    end do

    ! Now traverse t(1:j) to compute cnt
    tmp = 0
    cnt = 0
    do i = 1, j
        if (t(i:i) == 'A') then
            tmp = tmp + 1
        else if (t(i:i) == 'D') then
            cnt = cnt + tmp
        else
            tmp = 0
        end if
    end do

    !
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Output the integer without any extra spaces and a newline
    write(*,'(I0)') cnt

end program main
```

Steps:

  1. Read the input string (we assume maximum length 200000? but the problem doesn't specify. We can use a large enough length).
  2. Build the new string t by replacing every "BC" with "D". We traverse the original string and build the new one without the "B" in "BC" and replacing both with a single 'D'. We use an index j for the new string.
  3. Traverse the new string (from 1 to j) and do the counting.
  4. Write the integer cnt without any formatting (using I0 format) to avoid extra spaces.

But note: the input string might be long. We have to set the character variable length to a maximum. The problem doesn't specify, but we can set it to 200000.

Important: We must not do any I/O in the middle.

So the entire Fortran program:

```fortran
program main
    implicit none
    character(len=200000) :: s, t
    integer :: i, j, n
    integer(kind=8) :: tmp, cnt  ! to match Java's long

    ! Read the input string (as a single token, which is the entire word)
    read(*,*) s
    n = len_trim(s)

    ! Build the new string t by replacing "BC" with "D"
    t = ''  ! Initialize to blanks? Actually, we are going to assign by index, so we can set to blanks and then assign.
    j = 0
    i = 1
    do while (i <= n)
        if (i < n) then
            if (s(i:i+1) == "BC") then
                j = j + 1
                t(j:j) = 'D'
                i = i + 2
                cycle
            end if
        end if
        ! If we are here, we take one character
        j = j + 1
        t(j:j) = s(i:i)
        i = i + 1
    end do

    ! Now traverse t(1:j) to compute cnt
    tmp = 0
    cnt = 0
    do i = 1, j
        if (t(i:i) == 'A') then
            tmp = tmp + 1
        else if (t(i:i) == 'D') then
            cnt = cnt + tmp
        else
            tmp = 0
        end if
    end do

    ! Output the integer without any extra spaces and a newline
    write(*,'(I0)') cnt

end program main
```
